text: well
um I've studied acting
um and I've been teaching it for a long
time uh I've been teaching it formally
since
1973 and I've taught in all kinds of
places and sometimes I've been required
um
as would be the case not now in my
career but certainly early in my career
on a faculty a faculty you
know um a faculty has to kind of achieve
something as a group and so a lot of
times um I've had to teach very uh
traditional things and very traditional
so um I'm I'm I know a lot
about um the varieties of methods that
there are uh for approaching acting and
I think the best thing I heard about it
one of my teachers said that um you know
you you can't really talk about acting
directly everything that we know to say
is couched in metaphors that's number
one it's not like teaching medicine or
or teaching architecture or even
music um because it has to do with uh
identity
and we don't really understand so much
about it and it's not something we can
touch or feel um and the changes of
identities have never been for
example translated into music like
Musical music is translated into notes
we haven't really translated what we do
into something that can be constantly
replicated with a result that we can
anticipate so there's something about it
that's a little mysterious
Ethel merman's son actually was one of
the most um um powerful uh teachers that
I had and he said simply you know the
actor's gift is the imagination and then
one very practical and gifted teacher
said you know acting is the ability that
believe that you are someone else so uh
people have all different ways of
talking about it but the first comment I
think is the most most honest it's all
couched in
metaphors and so I studied a variety of
methods um people always made fun of me
in acting school because I was always
taking notes but I was very interested
in what is this how is it again that
people can change before my eyes and
along the way of my studying acting and
also my um teaching acting I began to
see that my students sounded um a lot
alike and so um I wanted to show them
that no human being talks like another
human being there are people who are
identical um like you can have an
identical twin of your voice like there
are people who sound exactly like a
sibling in the tone of voice but nobody
talks alike and so I thought that one
place to study identity would be in the
actual speech of a given
person originally I was going around
um interviewing people uh because I
wanted to teach something about that
about individuality as it is captured in
in in the actual physical physiological
mechanism of making sounds um we are
linguistic
animals um and then along the lines of
doing that u i developed this method
through which I make plays which is that
I interview people um I take something
that they said and and I attempt to say
exactly what they said uh more than word
for word utterance for utterance because
I have come to see that it's in the way
the utterances themselves are
manipulated that identity comes forward
so that's what I've been um studying and
practicing for a very very long time and
I have to say the thing that's
unquenchable about me is something I
told you about earlier really what I
really really love to do um is to listen
to people and listen to stories and so
over the past well I guess I have to
admit it's a little more than 30 years
now um if I've been learning anything
it's um that I've been learning more and
more about listening and I'm I never get
tired of it never get
tired well the first thing is that it is
it is the actual making of language the
actual the in the present moment sound
that a person is making and how they're
making that sound that's where identity
lives I think I I don't think it really
lives in like if you took my what I'm
saying here and you transcribed it um I
don't think that's Anna
deith um but I think that a series of um
sounds and movements are Anna De Smith
in other words the outward product of of
that and um you know your your your
language is is close to your breathing
it's close to your heart and uh usually
what I like to listen for is the time
when somebody says something in an
unusual way in that usually I talk to
people for about an hour and uh for
example if they're constantly using
upward inflections you know always
speaking up you know everything they say
goes up which
younger people tend to
do uh as I heard a very accomplished uh
judge
say uh when asked what advice she could
give to young women lawyers who are
trying to make it is don't do that
because what does it say to the judge if
you come forward and say your honor my
client is not guilty sounds like a
question right so if someone's talking
all like that what I'm going to listen
for is the time that they don't do that
and that's what I would start to study
as a way of characterizing them whereas
I think a professional mimic or an
impressionist would pick the thing they
do the most because that's what you an
audience could then um identify as that
person so an impression that's doing
George Bush is going to try to find the
gestures and the um you know the
intonations that he keeps using over and
over again but if I were to study him
and I haven't really um I'd look for
when he did something that wasn't what
we've
seen well that's a really wonderful
question um well I would say uh
President Clinton for
example uh was I went to Washington and
I interviewed 520 people or more um
and uh I was surprised that I would say
of those people the person Clinton was
probably among the five who had the most
musicality in their language in other
words um in Washington I would say you
begin to find less and less expression
than you find in other places because
people are very careful about what they
say they're going to be judged for what
they say they could say uh the wrong
thing or say it the wrong way and never
live
down so they have as someone said very
eloquently what Thomas Jefferson had
which is that Thomas Jefferson could
never be found in verbal
undress and so I was and so that kind of
verbal
dressing makes it harder to find music
in the language I'm trying to find the
time that people start to sing I call it
singing not actually you know la la la
la la but they really start to open up
rhythmically uh more than again what's
the text it's more about this singing as
I call it and I was surprised at the
extent to which Clinton sang and the
other thing um about Clinton that I
enjoyed was that he brought truth to
something that a linguist had actually
told me many years ago when I I told her
what I was trying to do that is to say a
form of getting people to sing she had
said to me well I'm going to give you
three questions that can ensure that
that that will happen in the course of
an hour if you only have an hour to talk
to people and the three questions were
have you ever come close to
death um uh do you know the
circumstances of your birth and have you
ever been accused of something that you
didn't do now when I first started my
whole process which I call on the road a
search for American character all of my
plays are part of of that series um I
originally just sat with people who I
met on the streets of New York and
talked them about whatever they you know
if they sold milk I talked about selling
milk or stick ball in the street in one
case um or uh being a lifeguard at the Y
um I'd sort of talk to them about what
they did and then somewhere in the
interview I'd ask those three questions
and lo and behold every time I did
people would start this singing that I'm
talking about so when I finally got an
interview with President Clinton which
wasn't easy and was told that I would
have 10 minutes alone with him in the
Oval Office I knew that I had to have a
question that would cause him to use the
entire 10 minutes without me having to
say anything and the question I picked
was a version of one of those three
questions and it was Mr President do you
think you're being treated like like a
common
criminal which is a version of have you
ever been accused of something that you
didn't do he spoke for 35
minutes and as people you know would
come into the office Mr President you
need to rest your voice now Okay bye so
I was really happy to see that something
that I learned you know you know 30
years before not quite 30 20 some years
before I met him actually was in good
stad as much as like you know I had
researchers I had everything in the
world to try to find the question I
should U ask President
Clinton no I think
um you know uh I can never remember
whether it's in Mark or
John in the
Bible where Pontius Pilate is supposedly
seeking the truth about Christ
and um you know and he says what is
truth you know is is it the
truth you know is the truth about this
man or is the truth about what will
happen if I make the wrong decision for
example I mean I'm quoting it very very
badly here but so I think
that there probably is not absolute
truth um but that doesn't mean that we
shouldn't seek to to find
facts uh it doesn't mean that we should
lie uh I think the reason lying becomes
so serious is
because to make a society to do things
to make buildings stand to do a heart
transplant um to do anything that is
important we have to know that the
people around us are telling us things
that are real if not true we have to be
able to rely on the things that that we
are told as fact uh because we want to
believe that someone went and tried
something first and therefore learned
that and they come and say well uh I've
been outside and it's raining today
right so we we learn to trust that make
decisions upon that
fact so I don't know if I'm really a
seeker of Truth in terms of like is
someone telling the truth um I think I'm
really a student of
um I'm a student of human
beings um yeah I think that's a better
way of putting it than that I'm a seeker
of truth I'm I'm a student of human
beings and their motivations and what
causes them to do what they say they're
going to do or what gets in the way of
that I think it's very hard in
fact not to see reality through the lens
of your own
experience and I also think it's
difficult
to put past experiences behind
us um
past
experiences that become that lens it's
very hard to change that lens and we
don't have a version of of uh surgery to
help us do that I suppose uh we used to
think that things like Psychotherapy
could help with it but now most people
go to a psychopharmacologist and they're
less interested in the process of
telling their myths to someone who uh
should understand them
and tearing those myths apart when they
don't help you know one of my favorite
artists uh uh is and was Jacob
Lawrence and um I interviewed him when
he was quite old and he was talking to
me about growing up Uptown in Harlem and
I was very interested in how somebody
who grew up Uptown um in Harlem would
would have um been able to mingle as
well as he did he was embraced by the
downtown art crowd that is to say the
white you know mainstream art crowd
embraced him uh his
work and you know he talked about how
when he was a boy if a white man were to
walk on the Street in Harlem or if he
were to go downtown and see white men
walking on the street he would
automatically think to himself that's a
lyncher so to him every white man was a
potential lyncher just like you know
there would be would have been white
people who would believe that every
black man is a potential rapist or Thief
well he thought every white man was a
potential
lyncher and so I said to him I said well
how did you get over that and he said
well you know he said the simplest thing
but it had such resonance I thought he
said you know
it's just like when you're a child and
you believe that there are ghosts and
goblins under the bed and then one day
you
don't and so many of us have different
kinds of ghosts and goblins we might
think that we aren't
so attractive cuz somebody told us that
or we might think that we're very
attractive that we should be on display
because somebody told us that or we
might
think um that we have to lie if we've
done something wrong so we have these
things uh these past experiences that
begin
to almost predict for us how we're going
to behave in any given
situation and I think it's very hard to
recraft
them um and I'm very interested in how
how people either succeed in recrating
those things or
not well actually in terms of listening
to stories uh the listening part I think
I have less of a problem with that
because you know I've been doing it for
a very long time and you know as I say I
I sit down with somebody and they could
tell me you know the ceiling is falling
um and I'm mostly listening to how they
said the ceiling was falling and I'm
missing the point that the ceiling is
falling so um I've really conditioned
myself to go in and listen for what I'm
listening for and so in that way I have
to say um I really people always ask me
set of you know how do I not judge
people and blah that is becomes
Irrelevant for me because I'm listening
to such a specific thing when I go in um
I think what's harder is how do I
train myself out of my habits in order
to inhabit them and take on on their
habits and that's hard and that comes
from repetition it just has to be you
know my grandfather told me when I was a
kid if you say a word often enough it
becomes you and that's really you know
my acting technique in a sentence is
this um belief that if I take someone's
words and repeat them over and over and
over and over and over again eventually
those words are going to hit my psyche
in a place that I understand who they
are really understand it which I
wouldn't understand from reading it or
hearing it the first time so I would say
the work that's really calls for that
has to do with reenacting more than
listening for the first time
